STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 21, 2023
Diedre Tyler
SAGINAW COUNTY DETENTION HOME
3360 HOSPITAL RD,
SAGINAW, MI, 48603-9622
Re: License #: CO730201394
SIR #:2023C0000599
Dear Ms. Tyler:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Tyler Armstrong, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(989) 264-9217
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CO730201394
Licensee Group Organization: Tenth Judicial Circuit Court of Michigan
Licensee Designee: Diedre Tyler
Chief Administrator: Diedre Tyler
Agency Name: SAGINAW COUNTY DETENTION HOME
Agency Address: 3360 HOSPITAL RD
SAGINAW, MI 48603-9622
License Status: Inspected
License Expiration Date: 08/10/2024
Capacity: 56
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
7/7/2023 10:30 AM Face to Face Documentation received or sent;
Unannounced Visit; Special
Investigation Initiation; Interview
7/10/2023 2:00 PM Face to Face Announced Visit; Interview
7/25/2023 9:00 AM Face to Face Announced Visit; Interview
7/25/2023 1:00 PM Face to Face Announced Visit; Interview
8/1/2023 8:30 AM Video Conference Interview
8/10/2023 4:32 PM Phone Interview
8/11/2023 11:59 AM Phone Pre-Exit Conference
8/18/2023 11:47 AM Phone Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10103 Program statement.
Section Rule 103. (1) A facility shall have a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Written policies and procedures pertaining to the
admission, care, and release of residents.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth escaped from the secure facility.
Investigation Complainant was informed of this incident on social media and
contacted DCWL staff on 07/05/2023.
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E were interviewed
during an unannounced face-to-face visit at the facility on
07/07/2023. All of the youth had similar recollections of the course
of events when Youth A escaped the facility. They recalled the
unit was outside in the yard playing football when staff had
instructed them to go inside, because Youth C was getting upset
and refusing to follow directives of staff. All of the youth in the unit
except for Youth C proceeded to go back into the building.
Youth C additionally stated Staff 1 was speaking with him and
attempting to de-escalate him when he noticed Youth A had come
back outside from the same door that all the youth had previously
used to enter back into the building. Youth C stated this only took
a couple of minutes. Youth C stated he did not want to be involved
in whatever Youth A was up to, so he decided to listen to staff and
go back inside the building. Before he went inside, Youth C stated
he heard Youth A say something to the effect of “I’m tired of being
here” and “I’m not getting no BMT for no reason.” Youth C
recalled a female staff attempting to go hands-on with Youth A but
was not able to. He could not recall who this staff member was.
Youth C stated this was the last he saw of Youth A until hearing
later that Youth A had escaped the facility. All of the youth were
asked if they had ever heard Youth A talking about wanting to
escape or having a plan to escape. Youth C stated he had heard
Youth A talking about trying to run away some time recently.
Youth C stated Youth A asked Youth C to go with him and Youth
A’s plan was to wait until they went outside and then climb the
fence. Youth C believed Youth E might have heard the same
thing. Youth C stated that he did not tell anyone else, youth or
staff, about these comments.
Youth E recalled a similar conversation with Youth A. Youth E
stated same day as the incident, Youth A had asked Youth E to
attempt to escape with him. This occurred when the unit was
outside playing football only minutes before Youth A ended up
attempting his escape. Youth E recalled hearing Youth A talk
about how he thought he could climb the fence and then go to a
clothing store to change outfits and attempt to steal a car at a gas
station. Youth E stated he felt like Youth A was serious but stated
2

that he did not tell anyone because he did not want to get involved
in any drama.
Youth B, Youth D, and Youth E all stated similar recollections of
being inside the gym when they saw Youth A run back out. They
stated that they were instructed to line up against the wall before
they were going to change their shoes by Staff 2. Very quickly
Youth A started to inch toward the door that went back outside
and then ran through the door. All three-youth stated that these
doors are normally locked and the only way to get through them is
to either be buzzed through from the control room, or from a staff
who has a key. All three youth did not know how Youth A was able
to get outside the door other than it was open.
Staff 1 was interviewed during an announced, face-to-face visit to
the facility on 07/10/2023. Staff 1 recalled Youth C was initially the
reason the entire unit had to come inside from playing football in
the yard. Staff 1 recalled Youth C being upset but could not recall
why. Staff 1 stated before he knew it, Youth A was back out in the
yard when the rest of the unit was inside. Staff 1 stated he
proceeded to walk Youth C back inside because Youth C had
chosen to be cooperative once Youth A went outside. Staff 1
stated other staff were still out in the yard with Youth A but could
not recall exactly who. Staff 1 stated he was able to have Youth C
go back to his unit and then he proceeded back out to the yard to
attempt to help de-escalate Youth A. Staff 1 recalled seeing Youth
A running around the yard and his emotions would quickly move
from him laughing and happy to frustrated and angry. He could not
recall everything Youth A said, but Staff 1 did recall hearing Youth
A say something to the effect of “she makes me so mad” and Staff
1 assumed Youth A was referring to Staff 2, the other female staff
working with the unit that day. Staff 1 also recalled hearing Youth
A say, “I miss my mama” as well as saying “they trying to play me
in court” and “I don’t wanna talk about it no more.” Staff 1 stated
he was out in the yard with Staff 3 and Staff 4. They were all
attempting to manage the environment and talk to Youth A to try
to de-escalate him and get closer to him. Staff 1 stated he heard
Youth A escalating more and more as Staff 4 got closer to him.
Staff 4 then removed himself from the situation and went back
inside to the gym in an attempt to remove himself as a trigger for
Youth A. Staff 1 stated he and Staff 3 were within 15 feet or so of
Youth A at one point when Youth A quickly attempted to scale the
fence. Staff 1 stated this occurred right at a point where there is a
locked gate in the fencing. Staff 1 recalled Youth A was able to
make his way up and over the fence well before he or Staff 3 were
able to get near him. Staff 1 stated he was almost able to touch
3

Youth A’s foot before he made it over, as a reference to how close
the two individuals were. Staff 1 stated he ran back inside the gym
and through a small hallway and back outside to a small
courtyard. Staff 1 stated he did this because he knew there was a
second fence Youth A would need to scale if he was attempting to
escape. Staff 1 wanted to maintain line of sight even if Youth A
had already made it over the fence. Staff 1 stated by the time he
got through this pathway to the second fence Youth A, had
already scaled the fence and was almost out of his line of sight
running south. Staff 1 stated he ran back inside to get outside to
the parking lot. He got in his car and drove to a nearby street in an
attempt to see if Youth A would run by. Staff 1 stated he did see
Youth A running in the opposite direction from him and Youth A
was starting to run through backyards. Staff 1 stated before he
was able to make a move to get closer Youth A disappeared into a
nearby woods. Staff 1 recalled Staff 3 and Staff 5 met up with him
at the same spot. Staff 1 recalled further efforts in the neighboring
area to attempt to find Youth A which were ultimately
unsuccessful. Staff 1 stated he has never seen a youth even
attempt to climb the fencing in the yard like Youth A did that day.
He stated he believed the fencing on the property was adequate
considering its overall height and the top half of it had much
smaller chain-link that was intended to be anti-climb fencing. Staff
1 did not believe Youth A would attempt to jump the fence during
his escalation in the yard because this happens on occasion and
staff have always been able to spend the time and eventually de-
escalate a youth outside and get them inside. Staff 1 also stated
he never heard Youth A say that he was going to try to escape or
try to scale the fence. Staff 1 recalled confusion as to how Youth A
was able to get back outside from the gym. He stated the doors in
the facility are all on locking mechanisms and heavy, and staff are
also all trained to make sure they visually see a door shut
because of the secure nature of the programming.
Staff 2 was interviewed during an announced face-to-face visit at
the facility on 07/10/2023. Staff 2 recalled the unit was outside
playing football and Youth C started to become upset. When
Youth C refused to come inside, all the staff agreed to have the
rest of the unit come inside to the gym while staff worked to de-
escalate Youth C. Staff 2 stated she was the first staff to come
inside with the youth, including Youth A, no one seemed upset, or
was giving her a hard time about coming inside. Staff 2 also
recalled Staff 4 eventually coming inside briefly. Staff 2 recalled
Youth A was not where he was supposed to be on the wall. Staff 2
instructed him to move over to where the other youth were sitting
on the wall. Staff 2 stated he started walking that way, and as she
4

looked to the right, she quickly realized Youth A had taken off and
ran towards the door. Staff 2 stated she did not see how Youth A
ran out the door, but it was obvious he had been able to do so
immediately. Since she was the only staff inside the gym, she
stayed inside to maintain line of sight and supervision of the rest
of the unit. Staff 2 recalled receiving instruction from Staff 6 that a
lockdown was going to proceed so she walked the rest of the
youth back to the unit. Staff 2 stated she did not see Youth A
again and was not involved in any efforts in the yard to try to de-
escalate him or react to his escape. She stated she did not know
until later he had escaped when many of the staff were
communicating and working out a plan to get outside to try to find
him. Staff 2 stated she believed that the door from the gym back
out to the yard had to have been open or unlocked somehow for
Youth A to make it back outside so quickly. Staff 2 described her
experiences working with Youth A prior to this incident. She stated
when he was mad he would run around and attempt to flip tables
and sometimes escalate more physically towards youth or staff,
but she believed he was usually able to be de-escalated with time
and attention. She stated she never heard him say anything about
attempting to run or escape from the facility. She did recall hearing
him talk about being excited to go outside to play football that day
in a manner that was not necessarily normal for him, but that this
was not something that she thought anyone would have thought to
act on in the moment considering that it was a nice day and all of
the youth tend to enjoy going outside.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 07/10/2023 during an announced face-
to-face visit at the facility. Staff 3 stated he was outside with the
unit when Youth C started to get upset. Staff 3 stated he turned
his attention directly to Youth C and attempted to manage him and
try to de-escalate. Staff 4 recalled all of the youth had no problem
going back inside from the yard and he thought that was because
it was about time to go inside as expected anyway. Staff 3 stated
he worked to have all of the other youth go back inside together.
He recalled seeing Youth A go inside with the rest of the youth.
Staff 4 recalled Staff 2 went inside with this group of youth.
Initially, Staff 1, Staff 3 and Staff 4 were outside with Youth C.
Staff 3 recalled Staff 4 must have gone to the door or stepped
inside at some point during this interaction. Staff 3 stated before
long the situation changed drastically when he saw Youth A run
outside from the gym. Staff 3 clarified he did not actually see
Youth A exit through the gym door back outside, but that he kind
of “just appeared.” Staff 4 recalled hearing Youth A say “I’m tired
of this.” Staff 3 thought he heard Youth A refer to being upset with
Staff 2 in some form but he was not sure what this meant. He did
5

recall hearing Youth A state “She’s always going off on me.” Staff
3 stated he and Staff 1 attempted to make contact with Youth A
but we’re not able to do so. Staff 3 also recalled during this time
Youth C had changed his behavior and decided to go back inside
with the rest of the unit. Staff 3 stated he and Staff 1 stayed
outside to keep working with Youth A. He recalled Youth A’s
attitude going up and down between being mad and laughing.
Staff 3 recalled during some points Staff 4 and Staff 6 were
outside as well but they eventually went back inside. Staff 3
recalled hearing Youth A say “The only people who try to talk to
me are you two” but Youth A did not allow them to get close
enough to him to stop the situation. Staff 3 stated when Youth A
was walking towards them and nearing the doorway to go back
inside to the gym he believed Youth A was giving off mannerisms
that he was ready to give in and go inside. Staff 3 recalled seeing
Youth A quickly scale the fence without saying anything else. Staff
3 stated he stayed outside to provide line of sight when Staff 1 ran
inside to attempt to meet Youth A over the fence. Staff 3 stated
Staff 1 “did not stand a chance” to catch up with Youth A because
Youth A scaled the first fence and then the second in quick
succession. Staff 3 stated he, Staff 4 and Staff 5 all ran outside
and got in a car to attempt to follow Youth A. He stated they did
not see Youth A when they were outside and they eventually met
up at a nearby street corner with Staff 1. Staff 3 stated he
eventually went out on foot into the woods and attempted to call
out for Youth A. Staff 3 could not recall how long he did this for
until supervision radioed for all staff to come inside because law
enforcement was now looking for Youth A. Staff 4 stated the entire
length of time in the yard was about 10 to 15 minutes. He stated
he was never within an arm’s length of Youth A during this
time. He never believed Youth A was going to attempt to jump the
fence because it is somewhat common for youth to be escalated
or upset in the yard, and a common response from them is to
refuse to come inside. Staff 3 stated staff are always able to work
the situation so that youth end up inside and he has never seen
anyone attempt to scale this fence. He specifically noted he never
heard Youth A talk about wanting to run or wanting to escape in all
his time working with him. Staff 3 stated he did not feel like there
was much that could have been done differently in the situation.
Youth A was interviewed during an announced face-to-face visit
to his new placement in jail on 07/25/2023. Youth A stated he had
been placed at the facility prior for about 11 months. He stated
that he had been outside playing football with his unit when they
were all instructed to go inside because Youth C was
struggling. Youth A stated he came back inside to the
6

gym. When asked, Youth A stated he did not have a concrete
plan in that very moment that he wanted to try to escape but he
had thought about it in the past and believed that he could do
it. Youth A stated once inside Staff 2 had told him to “Be quiet,
hold that” and this made him mad. Youth A stated he noticed the
door to the gym was open slightly so ran directly toward it and
through it. He was not sure if Staff 2 saw him or not or who was
on the other side of the door, but he did not believe Staff 4 or
anyone else was holding it. Youth A recalled once he was outside
he saw Youth C with Staff 1, Staff 3 and Staff 4. He stated he was
then wandering the yard and making a point not to let any of the
staff get near him. Youth A recalled talking to staff, especially
Staff 1 and Staff 3, but could not recall what he said in any of
those moments. Youth A remembered at some point he took off
his shoes and his socks. Youth A stated there was not anything
that staff did in that moment that caused him to attempt to scale
the fence and escape, he just thought he could do it and that was
the right time to try. Youth A stated he didn’t think it was as
difficult as he previously thought to get up and over the fence
because he was able to get his feet and hands in the seams
between the posts that created the large gate in the
fencing. Youth A stated he got over the first fence and then
immediately scaled the second fence that was about 20 feet
away. From that point he stated his memory was a bit fuzzy, but
he recalled running through backyards and a nearby woods and
then a field. Youth A believed he saw Staff 1 and Staff 3 on the
outside of the facility, but he was not sure if they saw him. Youth
A stated he was eventually able to get a ride from a stranger and
make it back to his mother’s home where he encountered law
enforcement later in the night and surrendered peacefully. Youth
A stated he had spoken to other youth, who he refused to name,
about the idea of escaping from the facility but that he was
positive that staff never heard him. He also believed that, even
though he was mad at her at the time, Staff 2 was not at fault for
the situation because he did not think she knew the door from the
gym to the yard was still open at all.
Staff 4 was interviewed with Staff 5 as a support person on
07/25/2023 during a scheduled meeting at a neutral
location. Staff 4 was not assigned to work with this particular unit
and was called in to the situation when Youth C began to refuse to
come inside. Staff 4 stated he made his way through the gym
outside to the yard and encountered the youth in the unit and Staff
1 and Staff 3 outside in the yard. As he went outside Staff 4
recalled hearing Staff 2 tell him inside the gym that the staff
outside needed help. As Staff 4 walked out, he remembered the
7

door already being open and not locked. Staff 4 stated he held
the door ajar just a little from the outside because he believed
other staff might have been coming out to assist. Staff 4 recalled
Youth C being escalated and upset. Staff 4 stated Youth A ran
out of the gym to the yard. Staff 4 recalled turning his attention to
Youth A, but he did notice Youth C quickly changed his behavior
and decided to go inside to the gym. Prior to Youth A running
back out to the yard, Staff 4 recalled also thinking that he had no
reason to be concerned about Staff 2 being the staff providing
supervision to the youth in the gym prior to Youth A running back
out. Staff 4 stated he joined Staff 1 and Staff 3 in attempting to
talk to Youth A, but at some point Youth A stated he did not want
to talk with Staff 4 if he was outside with them. Staff 4 agreed to
remove himself and go back inside. He stated this is a common
tactic to work toward de-escalation with youth in that sometimes
staff are a target of their anger and frustration and there always
should be enough staff around to swap out. Staff 4 stated the
youth from the unit were already getting back to their unit when he
heard over the radio Youth A had escaped the yard and was
AWOL. Staff 4 recalled running outside to see if he could spot
Youth A before he got too far. Staff 4 believed he saw Youth A
briefly running away after getting over the second fence and into
the parking lot, but Youth A got away from him quickly. He stated
he initially went past the back of the assisted living facility that is
located next to the detention center. Staff 4 recalled moving to
other locations out past the property of the detention to no
avail. At some point Staff 5’s car joined him, and he got in with
her to come back to the facility. Staff 4 stated he has never seen
another youth try to go up the fence at the facility. He also had
never heard Youth A say anything of concern that could have led
anyone to believe he would attempt this. Youth A recalled some
of the safety precautions that have been trained at the facility,
including going around the fencing when staff first go outside to
check for any breaks and to check that the large gate is locked.
DHHS Caseworker and DHHS Supervisor were interviewed over
video conference on 08/01/2023. DHHS Caseworker did not
recall ever hearing anything of concern from Youth A about
wanting to or believing that he could escape the facility. She also
stated she did not have any concerns about the facility in her time
working with them during Youth A’s placement.
Staff 6 was interviewed over the phone on 08/10/2023. She
stated she was involved in the situation but only over the phone
while on duty at the facility. Staff 6 had heard Youth A had
refused to come in from the yard. She stated that she was inside
8

the facility talking with other staff on what to do to try to address
Youth A’s behavior when she heard over the radio that Youth A
escaped. At that point she assisted with a building lockdown.
The facility’s Chief Administrator was interviewed over the
phone on 08/18/2023. She confirmed that an element of staff
training is to teach all staff to check doors behind them while
passing through them in the secure part of the facility. She
clarified that some doors are “heavy” and close and then lock on
their own, and some need to be manually locked. This requires
staff to check each door that they exit through to ensure it is
closed and locked as designed.
Tour observation:
A tour of where the incident occurred was conducted on
07/10/2023 during an announced face-to-face visit to the
facility. The secure facility has a gymnasium that has two exits to
the outside. The north exit was not utilized in this incident, but the
south door was. This south door locks from both sides. Only
certain staff have a key to exit the building and anyone else
utilizing the door need to be buzzed through by the control
room. The south door then opens up to the large yard area. The
entire area is enclosed by fencing that is approximately 20 feet
tall. The bottom half of the fencing is comprised of normal chain
link and the top half is comprised of a much tighter chain link that
does not allow for fingers to grip. This is designed to be anti-climb
fencing. The only exit in the fencing is a gate that is a few feet
south of the door to the gym that is used for maintenance and
yard work purposes. This gate is closed with a large padlock that
was present during the tour. On the other side of this gate is a
courtyard that extends west into other parts of the building and
south to another set of fencing. This set of fencing is of equal
height and has an identical gate in it facing south to the parking lot
and the outside of the secure parts of the facility.
Documents reviewed:
• Facility policy titled “AWOL – Prevention and Intervention”
was provided and reviewed. This policy was applicable in
that it was consistent with the de-escalation efforts of staff
prior to Youth A’s escape.
• Facility policy titled “Emergency Procedures: AWOL: (From
the Facility)” was provided and reviewed. This policy was
applicable in that it was consistent with the efforts made by
staff to locate Youth A after his escape from the facility.
• Incident Reports numbered 117795, 117797, 117802,
117803, 117804, 117806, and 117807 were provided and
9

reviewed. They were authored by Staff 2, Staff 5, Staff 4,
Staff 6, Staff 3, and Staff 1 respectively and all dated for
07/03/2023 on the date of the incident. All of these incident
reports but one detailed individual staff accounts of the
incident in question. These reports are consistent with the
interviews provided in the investigation. The last incident
report authored by Staff 3 details investigative questions
posed to youth in the unit in the aftermath of the incident,
and no information is contained that is inconsistent with the
interviews in this investigation.
• Video footage of the gymnasium was provided and
reviewed. Youth are beginning to come inside the gym
from the south door that exits to the outside yard at 5:15:40
pm. They all line up against the south wall of the gym. At
5:16:35 pm it can be seen that Staff 2 addresses Youth A
and points toward the wall. At 5:16:54 pm Youth A can be
seen quickly running toward the door and exiting through it.
It cannot be distinguished from this video footage if the
door was open or not at that point because there is a small
hallway from the east wall to the door that exits to the yard
that obstructs some of the view. No video footage of any
outside areas was available because there are no cameras
that capture that area of the facility.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as a youth was able to
escape the facility when a staff kept an exit door ajar, allowing the
youth to exit the building and scale the fence.
Technical Assistance
During interviews it was reported staff are trained to check doors
to ensure they are secure. Facility does not have any written
policy/training outlining this requirement. Facility should update
documentation accordingly to ensure doors are secure at all times
and not remained open if not currently being used.
It was discussed with Chief Administrator that appropriate
alterations could be made to the fencing surrounding the outside
yard area to reduce the chance of youth attempting or escaping
from the facility again. Different pictures of other court operated
facility fencing was provided along with a specific fencing
company.
Conclusion Violation Established
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
08/18/2023
_________________________________________________
Tyler Armstrong Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 21, 2023

Area Manager
11
